title: Chest-Over-Drawer

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of white pine, iron, brass, and paint.

artist_display:
Attributed to Robert Crosman
American, 1707–1799
Taunton, Massachusetts
description: This chest belongs to a group of furniture attributed to drum maker and joiner Robert Crosman, who likely learned the furniture-making trade from family members. The piece's simple plank construction is characteristic of Crosman's work. Although the flat top is undecorated, a white tree with ocher leaves and red flowering buds, and four birds surround the initials "H B" on the central panel. Early painted chests were likely made for young women as dowry vessels. The inclusion of women's initials on chests, as well as the use of a decorative vocabulary that bespeaks fertility and prosperity, supports this long-standing view. The initials on known Crosman chests are thought to be those of his sitters and other women in his family; the initials on this chest could be those of Hannah Blake, a relative of Crosman's second wife.
medium_display: White pine, iron, brass, and paint
inscriptions: Roman capital initials in white on either side of original iron lock plate: "H B"
publication_history: Meyric Rogers, "American Decorative Arts at the Art Institute of Chicago," The Magazine Antiques, LXXIV (July 1958), 49-56 (ill.). Helen Comstock, American Furniture, New York, 1962, no. 180 (ill.). Joseph T. Butler, Field Guide to American Antique Furniture, New York, 1985, no. 6 (ill.). Marvin D. Schwartz, "New Wing Presents Design, Colonial Period to Present," Antiques and Arts Weekly, December 30, 1989, 38-39 (ill.). Judith A. Barter and Monica Obniski, For Kith and Kin: The Folk Art Collection at the Art Institute of Chicago, (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2012), no. 4. Emelie L. Gevalt, "Revisiting Taunton: Robert Crosman, Esther Stevens Brazer, and the Changing Interpretations of Taunton Chests" (MA thesis, University of Delaware, 2017), 120-122 (ill.). Mark Pohlad, "Shooting and Collecting the Great Depression: A Review of 'Photography + Folk Art' at the Art Institute," Newcity Art, last modified Oct. 15, 2019, https://art.newcity.com/2019/10/15/shooting-and-collecting-the-great-depression-a-review-of-photography-folk-art-at-the-art-institute.
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, Photography + Folk Art: Looking for America in the 1930s, Sept. 21, 2019–Jan. 19, 2020, no cat.
